title: Becton Wildcats football team stuns Saddle Brook in fourth quarter
text:
Becton Wildcats football team stuns Saddle Brook in fourth quarter October 19, 2015 Last updated: Monday, October 19, 2015, 11:15 AM By Edward Kensik 
EAST RUTHERFORD - Becton's football team did not give up even when it was down by double digits in the fourth quarter on Saturday. 
And head coach Jack Maher can always tell his team in the future to not give up. 
The Wildcats came from being down 15 points with 10 minutes left to come all the way back for a 35-34 win, with a final-minute score and stun the home Saddle Brook crowd on Saturday afternoon in the NJIC Meadowlands Division. 
"It was an incredible win," said Maher who is in his first season as head coach for the Wildcats who are now 5-1. "Sometimes the football gods shine on you." 
Maher is talking about how the Wildcats senior linebacker Dominic DeLizio recovered a missed handoff with a little more than four minutes left in the game on the Saddle Brook 13-yard line. 
Becton quarterback Michael Bolwell hit junior wide receiver Seven Strong for a 13-yard touchdown. Bolwell hit Strong on a two-point conversion to slice the Saddle Brook lead to seven, 34-27 with four minutes remaining in the game. 
The Wildcats didn't kick the extra point because their usual kicker, James Loremikan, suffered a wrist injury in the first half that kept him out of the game. "He (Loremikan) kept asking me if he could come out and kick the extra point, but I couldn't risk that," said Maher about Loremikan who had a sling wrapped around his right arm. 
But fortunately Becton didn't need the kicking on this day. 
Becton tried an onside kick that failed and Saddle Brook recovered the ball on its 39-yard line. "They were moving the ball very well, and we had to take a chance," said Maher about going for the onside kick instead of squibbing the ball. 
The Wildcats had to exhaust their timeouts, but forced the Falcons to go three and out. 
On the punt return Strong ran it back 17 yards to the Becton 47 so the Wildcats had to go 53 yards with a little less than three minutes remaining in the game. 
And Becton took to the air as Bolwell would systematically move down the field and connect on four consecutive passes to get the Wildcats to the Saddle Brook 4 yard line. 
And then the sophomore signal caller took it in his own hands as he sprinted down the middle four yards for a touchdown with 90 seconds left in the game, cutting the Saddle Brook lead to 34-33. "It was a read option, and I just saw the opening," said Bolwell. 
Without Loremikan, Maher had no choice but go for the two-point conversion and the win. 
And it was the combination again of Bolwell-Strong as the quarterback connecting with Strong in the backfield, and the junior wide out took it the rest of the way to give Becton the 35-34 lead. "It was just a normal roll out play," said Bolwell. 
But Saddle Brook had some time remaining to comeback. But sophomore Nico Failla and the rest of the Wildcats defense would not let Saddle Brook quarterback Robert Lazzaro and the Falcons come back. 
Failla, brother of the starting Becton tailback Gianni Failla, would pick off a Lazzaro pass with 52 seconds left and secure the big victory. 
"This team really came together as a team," said Bolwell about the comeback. "We just dug deep and came together." 
Bolwell would lead the way for the comeback, completing 18 of 29 passes for 238 yards, three touchdowns and the rushing touchdown. 
For Becton the combination of Bolwell and Strong has developed into a lethal combination especially since both have made their debut on the varsity this year with Bolwell transferring from St. Joseph. Strong caught six passes for 66 yards and also a pair of two-point conversion catches. 
"They work very well together," said Maher about the pairing and who added about Bolwell. "Every game he is throwing better and better. He makes every throw work." Â© 2015 North Jersey Media Group Tags:
